title: Adapt v5
description: A sample course demonstrating the capabilities of the Adapt Framework
body: Welcome to the demonstration build for version 5 of the Adapt framework.

_buttons.disabledAriaLabel: This button is disabled at the moment

_glossaryItems.description: In or behind the stern of a ship. Nearer the stern than; behind. "the yacht has a shower just abaft the galley".
A way to signal the affirmative; "OK"
someone who wears glasses
At right angles to the keel of the boat, but not on the boat.
On or in the boat.
On the deck.
Side by side; by the side of.
American Boat and Yacht Council, Inc.
Loose, not secured to mooring or towlines.
On the water.
Toward the rear or stern of the boat.
A continued cooling of a patient's core temperature during the initial stages of rewarming from hypothermia.
Touching bottom.
In a forward direction.
Markers on land or sea which are located to enable navigators to avoid danger and fix their position.
Away from the direction of the wind. Opposite of windward.
Above the deck of the boat.
A rapid increase or accumulation in the population of algae in freshwater or marine water systems, and is recognized by the discoloration in the water from their pigments
Center or middle of the boat.

1. An iron casting shaped to grip the lake bottom to hold the boat.
2. The act of setting the anchor.
A line used to hold a vessel fast to the anchor.
On the shore.
Toward the stern.
A maneuver in which a ship's propelling mechanism is used to develop thrust in a retrograde direction.
At right angles of the center of the vessel.
The motion of receding waves.
To remove water from the bottom of the boat with a pump, bucket, sponge, etc.
A miniature livewell used to store and keep live bait alive and healthy.
Secure hatches and loose objects both within the hull and on deck.
The widest point on the boat.
Relative position or direction of an object from the boat.
Beneath the deck; within the cabin.
Location on rope or line where knot is made.
The lowest interior section of the boat hull.
Fan activated prior to starting engine, used to guide reaction exhaust gases away from a controlled combustion inside an engine compartment (bilge).
The raised areas or aluminum extrusions on the bottom of a boat that parallel the keel.
A short shaft with a fitting at one end shaped to facilitate use in putting a line over a piling, recovering an object dropped overboard, or in pushing or fending off.
To enter the boat.
Of the sea or clouds, turbulent and stormy.
A body of water between two areas of jurisdiction; e.g., a river between two states.
The front of the boat.
The location from which a vessel is steered and its speed controlled. "Control Station" is really a more appropriate term for small craft.
Vertical partition (wall) in a boat.
Carpeted trailer hull supports.
An anchored float used for marking a position on the water or a hazard or a shoal and for mooring.
Term for the boat that must “give-way” to boats with the right-of-way.
A flag bearing the colors or emblem of a sailing club, typically triangular.
A plate that provides maximum weight capacity and engine horsepower rating information. It is located in full view of the helm.
To turn over. Carburetor Back Flame Arrestor A safety device
To unfasten mooring lines in preparation for departure.
A twin-hulled boat, with hulls side by side.
A lengthwise imaginary line which runs fore and aft with the boat’s keel.
The point on a boat where the side intersects (meets) the bottom.
A fitting through which anchor or mooring lines are led. Usually U-shaped to reduce chafe.
A deck fitting with ears to which lines are fastened.
Also called helm. The steering wheel area of the boat.
Direction in which boat is navigated and steered.
The main battery used for engine starting and electrical circuits.
A small shelter cabin in a boat.
Water moving in horizontal direction.
The area encompassed from dead ahead of your boat to just abaft your starboard beam. You must stand clear of any boat in the "danger zone".
A fixed navigation structure used in shallow water upon which is placed one or more daymarks.
Directly ahead.
Directly aft.
A sunken or partially submerged log.
The navigational art of determining your position based on course steered and speed rather than through obtaining a position from other means; using a chart or electronic device.
The open surface on the boat where the passengers walk.
Special long-running batteries which can be repeatedly discharged and recharged without significant loss of power.
A small open boat. A dinghy is often used as a tender for a larger craft.
The weight of water displaced by a floating vessel, thus, a boat's weight.
A type of hull that plows through the water, displacing a weight of water equal to its own weight, even when more power is added.
A protected water area in which vessels are secured. The term is often used incorrectly to denote a pier or a wharf. The dock is the water adjacent to a pier or wharf.
The depth of water needed to float a ship. "the shallow draft enabled her to get close to shore".
A wood or metal plug stopping up the drainage hole near the keel of a boat and removable when the boat is dry-docked to drain out bilge water.

The method which is used to assist a ship in maneuvering during unavailability or inability of other boats to assist. A dredging anchor sniffing the bottom of the ship would hold the bow steady while allowing a ship to move fore and aft, this would shift the ship's pivot point forward.
The breakup of metals due to the effects of galvanic corrosion.

The point under International Rules of the Road (Navigation Rules) at which the privileged (or stand-on) vessel on collision course with a burdened (or give-way) vessel determines it must maneuver to avoid a collision. Prior to extremis, the privileged vessel must maintain course and speed and the burdened vessel must maneuver to avoid collision.
Unit of depth or measure; 1 fathom equals 6 feet.
Objects placed alongside the boat for cushioning. Sometimes called bumpers.
A knot in the form of a figure eight, placed at the end of a line to prevent the line from passing through a grommet or a block.
The second in command of a ship.
A pyrotechnic device used to signal a distress. The outward curve of a vessel's sides near the bow.
The part of an anchor that is designed to dig in to the bottom.
Fill with water and sink. To capsize or sink.
Toward the front or bow of the boat. Opposite of aft.
The distance from the water to the gunwale.
Rush of fresh water flowing into the sea.
The electrical device that is mounted on the outside of a built-in fuel tank and controls the dashboard fuel gauge.
The kitchen area of a boat.
The area of a ship's side where people board and disembark.
A term used to describe the vessel which must yield in meeting, crossing, or overtaking situations.
A form of position finding using radio transmissions from satellites with sophisticated on-board automatic equipment.
The rail or upper edge of a boat’s side.
An opening fitted with a watertight cover.
A marine toilet.
Forward motion, opposite of sternway.
The steering wheel or command area.
Person who steers a ship or boat.
A compartment below deck in a large vessel, used solely for carrying cargo.
The body of the boat.
A physical condition where the body loses heat faster than it can produce it.

1. More toward the center of a vessel; inside.
2. A motor fitted inside a boat.
A type of fuse located in the power wire of a direct current (DC) circuit usually near the battery.
Bays, rivers, and canals along the coasts connected so that vessels may travel without going into the sea.
A rope ladder, lowered from the deck, as when pilots or passengers come aboard.
A structure, usually masonry, projecting out from the shore. A jetty may protect a harbor entrance.
Small anchor used to reposition a ship or boat by having the anchor's hawser hauled in.
The lowest portion of the boat; extends fore and aft along the boats bottom.
The distance north or south of the equator measured and expressed in degrees.
Storage space in or around the stern area.
Direction away from the wind opposite of windward.
Sideways movement of a boat caused by wind or current.
A buoyant, wearable jacket that, when properly used, will support a person in the water. See PFD (personal floatation device).
Leaning or tilt of a boat toward the side.
A structure having movable gates for ships and boats to pass up and down to different water levels in a canal, river, or tidal basin.
A record of courses or operation. Also, a device to measure speed.
The distance in degrees east or west of the meridian at Greenwich, England.
Making progress through the water.
Seagoing maps showing depths, buoys, navigation aids, etc.
A single hull boat.
An anchor, chain or similar device that holds a boat in one location.
One minute of latitude; approximately 6076 feet—about 1/8 longer than the statute mile of 5280 feet.
The art and science of conducting a boat safely from one point to another.
Recognizable objects on land or sea, such as buoys, towers or lights which are used to fix position to identify safe and unsafe waters.
The regulations governing the movement of vessels in relation to each other, generally called steering and sailing rules.
The National Marine Manufacturers Association.
The speed at which a boat travels to produce an imperceptible wake.
Detachable engine mounted on the stern of a vessel.
Over the side and out of the boat.
When a vessel passes another vessel from behind.
Inhabiting the upper layers of the open sea.
Personal floatation device. A buoyant personal flotation device used to support a person in the water. See life jacket.
A wood, metal or concrete poles driven into the bottom. Craft may be made fast to a pile; it may be used to support a pier or a float.
See speedometer pickup tube.
A boat is said to be planing when it is essentially moving over the top of the water rather than through the water.
A hull designed to lift, thereby reducing friction and increasing efficiency.
A condition in which the bow bounces up and down caused by trimming the engine too far out.

1. The left side of a boat when facing the bow.
2. A destination or harbor
Term used for the boat with the right-of-way.
Term for the boat that has priority in meeting or crossing situations. The stand-on or privileged boat.
Typically seen as a collection of nests high in a clump of trees. A breeding colony of seabirds, wading birds, seals, or turtles.
A flat piece hinged vertically near the stern of a boat or ship for steering.
Regulations for preventing collisions on the water.
A through hull valve, a shut off on a plumbing or drain pipe between the vessel's interior and the sea.
Also called pitot tube. The plastic device that extends below the bottom of the boat. It connects to the speedometer with plastic flexible tubing.
The section of an outboard-equipped boat that is just forward of the transom.
Term for the boat that must maintain course and speed in meeting or crossing situations. The privileged boat.
The right side of the boat when looking toward the bow.
The back area of the boat.
To pack the cargo.

A casing in which material such as greased wool is compressed around a shaft or axle to form a seal against gas or liquid, used for instance where the propeller shaft of a boat passes through the hull.
A type of trailer braking system designed to automatically actuate when the tow vehicle’s brakes are applied.
The unit that sends/receives signals for the depth sounder.
The transverse beam across the stern.
Fore to aft and side to side balance of the boat when loaded.
Boat in motion; i.e., not moored or anchored.
The United States Coast Guard.
A hull with a bottom section shaped like a “V”.
A modified V-hull design with a small, flat area in the keel aft.
A device used to signal the need for assistance such as flags, lights and flares.
High waterproof boots, or a waterproof garment for the legs and body. Used especially by anglers when fishing.
The waves that a boat leaves behind when moving through the water.
A navigable body of water.
To steer off course.

_bookmarking.title: Resume?
_bookmarking.body: Would you like to resume the course from the location you were at last time?
